title: John Bernard MacGinley
text:
John Bernard MacGinley (August 19, 1871 – October 18, 1969) was an <a href="Ireland">Irish</a>-born clergyman of the <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Church">Roman Catholic Church</a>. He served as <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Archdiocese%20of%20Caceres">Bishop of Nueva Caceres</a> (1910 – 1924) and <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Diocese%20of%20Monterey-Fresno">Bishop of Monterey-Fresno</a> (1924 – 1932).
Biography.
John MacGinley was born in <a href="County%20Donegal">County Donegal</a>, the sixth of thirteen children of Thomas Colin and Margaret Theresa (née Sinnott) MacGinley. His father served as <a href="Principal%20%28education%29">principal</a> of <a href="Croagh">Croagh</a> <a href="National%20school%20%28Ireland%29">National School</a>, and was author of "General Biology" and several works on folklore and scenery of western Donegal. He was educated at <a href="St%20Eunan%27s%20College">St Eunan's Seminary</a>, <a href="Letterkenny">Letterkenny</a> and <a href="Blackrock%20College">Blackrock College</a>, <a href="Dublin">Dublin</a>, in his native country, and at the <a href="Pontifical%20North%20American%20College">Pontifical North American College</a> in <a href="Rome">Rome</a>.
While in Rome, MacGinley was <a href="Holy%20Orders">ordained</a> to the <a href="Priesthood%20%28Catholic%20Church%29">priesthood</a> by Archbishop <a href="Edmund%20Stonor">Edmund Stonor</a> on June 8, 1895. He earned a <a href="Doctor%20of%20Divinity">Doctor of Divinity</a> degree in 1896, and came to the <a href="United%20States">United States</a> that same year. He then served as a <a href="curate">curate</a> at <a href="https%3A//web.archive.org/web/20101227091649/http%3A//archdiocese-phl.org/parishes/7385.htm">Our Lady of the Rosary Church</a> in <a href="Philadelphia">Philadelphia</a>, <a href="Pennsylvania">Pennsylvania</a>, until 1898, when he became professor of <a href="Latin">Latin</a> and <a href="Ethics%20in%20religion">moral theology</a> at <a href="St.%20Charles%20Borromeo%20Seminary">St. Charles Borromeo Seminary</a>. He remained at St. Charles for five years, and was made <a href="Rector%20%28ecclesiastical%29">rector</a> of the seminary at <a href="Vigan%20City">Vigan City</a> in the <a href="Philippines">Philippines</a> in 1905. In 1910, he returned to Philadelphia, where he became a curate at <a href="https%3A//web.archive.org/web/20090814043126/http%3A//www.archdiocese-phl.org/parishes/7695.htm">St. Charles Church</a>.
On April 2, 1910, MacGinley was appointed <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Archdiocese%20of%20Caceres">Bishop of Nueva Caceres</a> in the Philippines by <a href="Pope%20Pius%20X">Pope Pius X</a>. He received his <a href="Bishop%20%28Catholic%20Church%29">episcopal</a> <a href="consecration">consecration</a> on the following May 10 from Archbishop <a href="Diomede%20Falconio">Diomede Falconio</a>, with Bishops <a href="John%20Edmund%20Fitzmaurice">John Edmund Fitzmaurice</a> and <a href="Edmond%20Francis%20Prendergast">Edmond Francis Prendergast</a> serving as <a href="Consecrator">co-consecrators</a>. Recalled to the United States, he was named <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Diocese%20of%20Monterey-Fresno">Bishop of Monterey-Fresno</a>, <a href="California">California</a>, on March 24, 1924. He later resigned due to ill health on September 26, 1932; he was appointed <a href="Titular%20Bishop">Titular Bishop</a> of <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Diocese%20of%20Croae">"Croae"</a> on the same date. He retired to <a href="Killybegs">Killybegs</a>, in his native County Donegal, where he died at age 98.
